newsitem.title: UK: Wetherspoon notes sales pick-up in August.
newsitem.headline: Wetherspoon notes sales pick-up in August.

text.p: Pub group J.D. Wetherspoon is seeing a pick-up in confidence amongst drinkers especially in the London area, said managing director Mark McQuater.
August sales were three percent higher than last year on a like for like basis.
"We are probably seeing a feeling of more confidence among pub-goers expecially in the London area, where we have the majority of our pubs," McQuater told Reuters.
Earlier, the company reported a rise in adjusted pretax profits to 13.11 million on turnover of 100.5 million in the year to July 31 up from 9.71 million on turnover of 68.54 million.
The main force behind the profits rise came from the 36 new pub openings in the year, compared with 23 the previous year, bringing the total number of outlets to 146.
A total 33 pubs were opened outside London compared with 11 the previous year.
Wetherspoon pubs are large, real ale, no music venues. Its non-London pubs are even bigger, generating higher turnover.
Wetherspoon shares were up 17-1/2p at 970 by 1300 GMT.
